SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: In paragraph 5, what does the phrase “held our breath” suggest about the narrator and Josh?

A.Choice: They are sneaking around the house to avoid being seen by Mother.

B.Choice: They are feeling thankful that Aunt Marjorie has left.

C.Choice: They are waiting anxiously to see what Mother will do next.

D.Choice: They are trying to avoid talking about The Hat because it is upsetting.

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: How does paragraph 5 contribute to the story's structure?

A.Choice: It foreshadows the resolution of the story.

B.Choice: It develops the narrator's feelings about Mother.

C.Choice: It explains Mother's problem in detail.

D.Choice: It gives background details that explain the story.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which quotation best supports a theme of the story?

A.Choice: “My mother believed in using things up.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “We looked at each other, then scouted the house.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “It wasn't hard to spot.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “Then we glanced over at the lamp.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator's or speaker's point of view influences how events are described.
Content: In paragraphs 8 and 9, how does the narrator's point of view influence the description of events?

A.Choice: The narrator thinks the events are funny, so she describes them in a humorous way.

B.Choice: The narrator thinks the events are boring, so she describes them in a dull way.

C.Choice: The narrator is confused by the events, so she describes them in a mysterious way.

D.Choice: The narrator is happy about the events, so she describes them in a joyful way.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 12.
:box:It was as though time stood still.
Which idea does the sentence develop?

A.Choice: Everyone was pleased.

B.Choice: Nobody moved or spoke.

C.Choice: Nobody wanted to leave.

D.Choice: Everyone was late.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: What can the reader infer from the details in paragraphs 17 and 18 of the story?

A.Choice: Mother worries that the crows will stop being afraid of The Hat and changes to a new hat every June.

B.Choice: Mother is concerned about the crows and gives them one month each year to eat what is in the cornfield.

C.Choice: Mother spends each June enjoying time with Aunt Marjorie and does not do much work in the cornfield.

D.Choice: Mother removes The Hat from the cornfield in June so that Aunt Marjorie's feelings will not be hurt.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: How are the narrator and Josh alike?

A.Choice: They both make comments that cause their mother to have new ideas.

B.Choice: They both are interested in watching their mother solve her problem.

C.Choice: They both contribute their old items to build the scarecrow for the field.

D.Choice: They both joke about how their dog is more attractive than the hat.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 1 of the article.
:box:In the days when farmers worked with ox and sled and cut the dark with lantern light, there lived a boy who loved snow more than anything in the world.
How does the author's word choice in the sentence affect the meaning of the passage?

A.Choice: by suggesting that the ideas in the passage are made up

B.Choice: by showing that the subject of the passage became famous

C.Choice: by suggesting that the topic of the passage is familiar

D.Choice: by showing that the events in the passage happened long ago

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What is the meaning of the word “pelted” as it is used in paragraph 3?

A.Choice: created

B.Choice: found

C.Choice: saved

D.Choice: threw

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which quotation best supports a main idea of the article?

A.Choice: “He expected to find whole flakes that were the same...” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “'Fussing with snow is just foolishness,' his father said.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “Even so his first pictures were failures...” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “'Now everyone can see the great beauty in a tiny crystal,' he said.” (paragraph 7)

SubTopics: Analyze multiple accounts of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.
Content: What does the information in paragraph 9 suggest about the author's point of view?

A.Choice: The author believes that Bentley could have been more careful.

B.Choice: The author respects Bentley's many different interests.

C.Choice: The author admires Bentley's dedication.

D.Choice: The author questions the methods Bentley used.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Which statement is true based on the information in paragraphs 6 and 11?

A.Choice: Bentley's work with snow required expensive equipment that he was willing to spend all his money on.

B.Choice: Bentley was thought to be foolish throughout his life because of his interest in snow.

C.Choice: Bentley's parents thought he should do something with his life other than taking pictures of snow.

D.Choice: Bentley became less interested in studying snow than in publishing pictures and giving speeches.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: What does the reader learn about Bentley from paragraphs 10 and 11?

A.Choice: He was more interested in sharing his work than in making money from it.

B.Choice: He worked hard to develop a way of making photographs of snowflakes.

C.Choice: He wanted to find out if all snowflakes were different from each other.

D.Choice: He was able to follow his interests because of the help he got from his family.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Which sentence best describes how the article is organized?

A.Choice: The reasons for Willie Bentley's experiments with snow are presented, followed by their eventual conclusions.

B.Choice: The events of Willie Bentley's life and his study of snow are described as they happened over time.

C.Choice: The different problems of photographing snow are explained and then Willie Bentley's solutions are described.

D.Choice: The important ideas about snow in Willie Bentley's discoveries are presented, followed by details and examples.

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: How do paragraphs 1 and 23 relate to each other?

A.Choice: They show the change in Gregor's life during the story.

B.Choice: They show what Gregor has learned in the story.

C.Choice: They show how MacTavish changes in the story.

D.Choice: They show the growth of MacTavish's fortune during the story.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: What does the phrase “marched back” in paragraph 14 suggest about MacTavish?

A.Choice: He is confused.

B.Choice: He is worried.

C.Choice: He is determined.

D.Choice: He is excited.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: How are Gregor and the man who sold the sheep to him similar?

A.Choice: They are both unskilled at selling things to people.

B.Choice: They both try to trick someone in order to make money.

C.Choice: They are both concerned with helping their family and neighbors.

D.Choice: They both believe that animals can have special qualities.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Which of Gregor's actions shows how he is different from MacTavish?

A.Choice: Gregor cheats another person.

B.Choice: Gregor buys a sickly sheep.

C.Choice: Gregor shares his wealth.

D.Choice: Gregor moves to a big house.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Which sentence is true about Gregor and MacTavish?

A.Choice: MacTavish has a plan for how the sheep will make him rich, but Gregor does not.

B.Choice: MacTavish wants to own big houses and many jewels, but Gregor does not.

C.Choice: Gregor wants to move away to another land, but MacTavish does not.

D.Choice: Gregor is generous with his family and his neighbors, but MacTavish is not.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence expresses a theme of the story?

A.Choice: Big loss can come from being greedy.

B.Choice: Family can make hard times seem easier.

C.Choice: Wealth may come from hard work.

D.Choice: Appreciating others can lead to happiness.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: Gregor goes to the market and talks to many farmers about their sheep.

B.Choice: Gregor's mother is asleep when Gregor takes money to buy the sheep.

C.Choice: MacTavish lives at another one of his houses after he buys the sheep from Gregor.

D.Choice: MacTavish goes to buy Gregor's sheep after he hears rumors about the animal.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: What idea is developed in paragraphs 4 through 7?

A.Choice: Wangari and her mother want to plant more trees.

B.Choice: Mugumo trees are important to people and animals.

C.Choice: Mugumo trees can provide shade to many people.

D.Choice: Wangari and her mother think education is important.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 8 of the article.
:box:Her mind was like a seed rooted in rich soil, ready to grow.
What does the sentence help the reader to understand about Wangari?

A.Choice: She likes to think about plants.

B.Choice: She wants to keep learning.

C.Choice: She imagines ways to help others.

D.Choice: She believes in working together.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: How are the details in paragraphs 13 and 14 organized?

A.Choice: as a description of how animal habitats changed

B.Choice: as an explanation of the solution to a problem in the environment

C.Choice: as a comparison of the village before and after the government sold the land

D.Choice: as a description of how a problem was caused in the area and its effects

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Paragraphs 17 and 18 explain that Wangari spread her idea by

A.Choice: sharing it with women around the country

B.Choice: giving it the name Green Belt Movement

C.Choice: watching the land in Kenya turn green again

D.Choice: planting trees herself everywhere she went

SubTopics: Analyze multiple accounts of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.
Content: Which sentence most likely expresses Wangari's point of view?

A.Choice: People can make the changes they want by working together with determination.

B.Choice: People change their traditions and customs with each generation.

C.Choice: People cannot rely on the government to help them in a time of need.

D.Choice: People in other countries do not need to work as hard on the same problem.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: How does the title of the article support a main idea?

A.Choice: It describes advice Wangari followed.

B.Choice: It describes how Wangari solved a problem.

C.Choice: It explains how Wangari felt about trees.

D.Choice: It explains which values Wangari's village held.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Based on the information in the article, where did Wangari most likely get her idea for planting trees across Kenya?

A.Choice: from the school she attended in the capital city

B.Choice: from the government of her country

C.Choice: from the women of the village where she grew up

D.Choice: from what her mother taught her as a girl
